Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: identity-attack and non-identity-attack. Identity attack refers to anything rude or disrespectful about someone's identity, including appearance, race, gender, and sexual orientation.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: It's bad enough we already have all these American sicko's living in this country shooting up theatre, schools, churches, malls, etc., we don't have room for crazy muslims.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on both American and Muslim.
This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: We are living in a cesspool.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Comment: I'm reminded of that landmark paper: _The Basic Laws of Human Stupidity_ by Carlo M. Cipolla, Former Professor of Economics at University UC Berkeley.

-First Law: Always and inevitably everyone underestimates the number of stupid individuals in circulation.
-Second Law: The probability that a certain person be stupid is independent of any other characteristic of that person.
-Third (and Golden) Law: A stupid person is a person who causes losses to another person or to a group of persons while himself deriving no gain and even possibly incurring losses.
-Fourth Law: Non-stupid people always underestimate the damaging power of stupid individuals. In particular non-stupid people constantly forget that at -all times and places and under any circumstances to deal and/or associate with stupid people always turns out to be a costly mistake.
-Fifth Law: A stupid person is the most dangerous type of person.
-Corollary to the 5th Law: A stupid person is more dangerous than a bandit.

Paul

Comment: Reading some of the comments indicating disagreement about the views expressed by Pope Francis and the decrees of Vatican II I cannot help thinking that some of the problems go all the way back to Vatican I and a clear understanding of what constitutes an infallible teaching. Some people seem to feel that any statement made by a bishop or monsignor in the Vatican is infallible while the other extreme is the gang who feel that only those formal statements by the pope to which they unanimously agree can claim infallibility. Francis seems to hold that the sensus fidelium is a relevant factor in the process. Others seem to point out that infallibility refers only to doctrinal pronouncements addressed to all the faithful, not to approval or disapproval of conduct by individuals.
If we can clarify what the dissenters mean by the teaching authority of the Church we can skip a lot of silly debates.
Bill Keane

Comment: This is the crux of the argument and I'm glad we're here.

We both want the same thing, we just have the exact opposite strategy.

I believe that people like Tyler and I (and probably you) stand to benefit from development. Because there just is not enough supply right now, and it's fucking everything up.

SF is, to my eye, the example of your approach while Seattle is my approach. In SF, they won't let anybody build anything but they have rent control—all that does now is lock-in the old Boomers, who hate their new market rate neighbors. Seattle built fast and rents there have actually fallen, finally, after that building boom. The upward pressure was relieved.

How will it play out? Well, I might be right and I might be wrong, but I think development will save Portland culture by stemming the insane lack of supply. And for this perspective I get a lot of flak.

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: The story’s title makes it appear that airline passengers are having problems with airline dress codes, when nothing of the sort is occurring.  This is an internal situation between United Airlines and its employees.   Airline employees and certain family members have free standby flight privileges and are required by United to meet company dress standards.  Not many long years ago, United employees travelling standby were required to adhere to very strict dress standards like coats and ties for men, dresses or slacks for women and no athletic shoes, even for children.  The standards have been relaxed and are now quite liberal, meaning almost anything is acceptable.  Nevertheless, United employees and family members must adhere to the dress code.  Those that do not want to have an option – they can pay for their ticket and dress like slobs.

Comment: What utter garbage! The Globe's editors are showing disgusting authoritarian tendencies with this tripe.

Senators have been appointed to do a job. In order to do this job, they have been given certain powers in full accordance with the constitution of Canada.

If you don't like the manner in which they exercise their powers, that's one thing - just part of the normal grumbling about politics that comes hand-in-hand with any issue. And if you don't like the powers they have, a very simple procedure is open to you: amend the constitution.

But to suggest that they should not exercise the powers with which they were entrusted due to some feeling that the constitution is a flawed document which should be ignored is simply contrary to the democratic process and is the first step to authoritarian rule.

Comment: The bottom line is that, if you don't want to conform to covenants and rules, don't buy a home in a covenant-controlled community.  The things that require compliance are known prior to the finalizing of the sales contract, and are agreed to by all the parties.  The covenants constitute a contract that runs with the land and is legally binding on all owners.  At closing, the buyer signs a statement that he agrees to this.  So it is disingenuous for an owner to later claim ignorance.  Before doing something, ASK FOR PERMISSION.  It's that simple.  In most cases, reasonable boards will work with owners.  But don't be a jerk, and then expect the board or the manager to give you any deference.  And don't automatically assume you're being singled out, for any reason, because you have no idea what action is being taken against other violators.

Comment: Surely for each person who cannot afford a house and who would like prices to drop, there is a homeowner who is deliriously happy about the increase in value (or is deeply in debt and needing the value of the house to hold up to support the loans) who would be very, very unhappy at having the government sabotage their financial position.
If the house values are not supported by economics, nature will take its course and the values will correct. If there is a legitimate demand backed by financial ability to pay, the values are fine as they are.
Governments can get involved if speculators allow empty homes to deteriorate -- not because of the price effect but because of the neighborhood effect -- but it is futile, expensive and dangerous to try to steer a market.
If immigration is a factor in house prices, that is something to consider in an overall evaluation of immigration policy. It's not a reason keep otherwise desirable immigrants out.

Comment: For 23 years.  the assumed rate of return was 8%.  IF the fund did not make 8%,  taxpayers had to make it up,  infill it.  If the return was MORE than 8%,  the PERS Board,  as constituted in those years by ALL PERS recipients and public employees,  awarded the windfall to the pensioners who got that money added annually for the rest of their PERS lives.   A great system of capitalism:  I get the gains and you make up the losses.  

So here is the deal,  if the fund makes more than 7.2%,  the pensioners get the extra money,  and if it does not make 7.2%,   the legislature  takes taxpayer   money from education,  transportation infrastructure,  DHS budgets   and infill the "loss" to make the poor dears whole.  Worse,  if you lowered the assumed rate of return as prognosticated by the actuaries,  it would be in the low 6% range,    and the unfunded liability would increase to the mid $50 billion range.  Damned if you do and damned if you don't.  Been that way since 1988 when R's died.

Comment: Actually I'm a centerist, more Libertarian than D or R. I also try to be a realist. As an engineer, my career was shaped by hard facts, not feelings. Truth is that we have limited resources. Oh, we're not going to run out of them next week, probably not in the next century. But as our population increases, so does the rate that we consume resources, the rate that we foul our nest. One of the reasons for our exponential population growth is that we strive to eliminate threats to our existence, destroying predators, curing disease, and trying to control natural disasters. If we stand back and let nature take its course, people will die.  As the weak & unfit die off, our race becomes stronger, better able to cope with the realities of life. It's Nature's way. 

BTW: The ACA had little to do with healthcare. It mandated no changes in the trajectory of costs or quality. The ACA was about INSURANCE and taxes.  And so were both of the GOP fix-it plans.

Comment: That's wrong.  It's a high standard, but not nearly that high.

Section 41 of the Constitution Act, 1982 provides that a constitutional amendment in relation to the office of the Queen, etc can be made "only where authorized by resolutions of the Senate and House of Commons and of the legislative assembly of each province."

 It does not require that resolutions pass by unanimous vote.  The usual standard of majority vote in each legislature is sufficient.

Elijah Harper's 'veto' came about because Manitoba left ratification until the last minute, and a unanimous vote was required to expedite debate and the vote on the Meech Lake accord.  Had the Manitoba government scheduled the debate earlier, there would have been no need for unanimity.

Comment: Mark, no one is ridiculing the concept of avoiding co-mingling of wild and domestic herds. The ridiculous part is the overly broad and vague terms used. 15 "air miles" would only be relevant if sheep learn to fly. Comment: A rather delayed response. Imagine that a retailer sells chicken for R 30/kg. The retailer has an invoice price for that chicken of R 25/kg meaning a R 5 GP. Written into the supply agreement is that the chicken supplier will pay for various marketing expenses via rebates, shelf fees etc. which costs the supplier R 5/kg.  The chicken supplier nets R 20/kg. If the retailer paid for all the marketing costs themselves the chicken supplier still gets R 20/kg, the retailer still sells the chicken for R 30/kg but the retailer GP is now R 10/kg. This changes the way the retailers books are presented.

1) Just because something is critical for life doesn't mean that more is better. Oxygen is critical for life, but too much will poison you. C02 is a greenhouse gas not a pollutant.

Those wavelengths are dominant compared to other greenhouse gases.

3&4) Climate models have predicted rising surface and ocean temperatures. That's happened. Don't confuse the actual science with things said by celebrities. Very few specific predictions have been made by credible institutions other than temperature estimates.

Comment: This is an interesting question and the answer is complex.  If availability of funds is unlimited then clearly spending any amount to reduce any bad thing is warranted.  In reality, resources are limited and decisions regarding optimal use of funds must be made.  For every decision to spend money on one thing, we spend less on something else.  In absolute terms, terrorist murder comprises a very small percentage of total murders, yet we spend far more money fighting terrorism than we do fighting other murder.  To do so is irrational, but that is who we are.  

More generally, I think that murder is reduced not through conviction and sentencing, but through broad public acceptance and support of the value of human life.  When we as a society treat people as disposable, dehumanize them, call them pond scum, drop bombs on them, or kill them via police, we teach individuals that it is okay to solve personal problems through murder, robbery, etc.  We reap the fruit of what we sow.

Comment: An Emperor owned a majestic white stallion, the finest beast in all his Kingdom. One night, a thief tried to slip in and steal the horse, but was captured by the palace guards and thrown into the dungeon.
The next morning, he was dragged before the Emperor's court. "How dare you," bellowed the Emperor, "lay hand on my royal steed! Jailor, put this thief to death!" 
Immediately, the thief bowed deeply. "Your judgement is peerless and wise, O Emperor," he calmly replied, "but my life is of little value. I should offer you a gift before I depart. Your mount is quite a fine one, but if your eminence would spare my life for just a year and a day, I swear to you I can teach that horse to sing.  To the surprise of all, the Emperor quickly accepted the offer.
The jailor whispered to the thief, "You are a fool!" You will be tortured when you fail.
" I am a fool?" Much can happen in a year and a day. The King may die. The horse may die. I may die... and maybe the horse will learn how to sing."

Comment: When the ADN focuses on Anchorage news, it gets complaints from other regions of the state. When it tries to provide a statewide news focus, it gets disparaged by Jenkins for not covering more Anchorage news.  The old damned if you do, damned if you don't.  The state of Alaska is a tough beat to cover by anyone's standards. 

Maybe Anchorage should strive to have its own paper again that really digs into the city's issues - I can agree with Jenkins that is likely wanted and needed and he makes some good points. 

I and my coastal family have appreciated the varied stories the ADN has strived to provide and it has done a good job of it. It's a travesty that so many people think nothing of paying for cable tv, iTunes, Netflix, etc. but won't pay a paltry sum to support a statewide newspaper.  

We are rooting for the ADN to survive and applaud the Alaskans who have come forward to save it. No matter how much griping goes on, it would be badly missed if it went away.
